revision.text:
{{Redirect|Uniport|the university|Uniport (Nigeria)}} {{Multiple issues| {{More footnotes|date=May 2015}} {{page numbers needed|date=May 2015}} }} [[Image:Porters.PNG|right|thumb|250px|Comparison of transport proteins]] A '''uniporter''' is an [[integral membrane protein]] that transports a single type of [[Substrate (biochemistry)|substrate]] species ([[Electric charge|charged]] or uncharged) across a cell membrane. It may use either [[facilitated diffusion]] and transport along a [[diffusion]] gradient or transport against one with an [[active transport]] process.<ref>[http://www.oxfordreference.com/abstract/10.1093/acref/9780198529170.001.0001/acref-9780198529170-e-20301?rskey=4US0W9&result=20204 Article in ''The Oxford Dictionary of Biochemistry and Molecular Biology'']</ref>. They can be either [[ion channel]]s or [[carrier protein]]s.
Uniporter carrier proteins work by binding to one [[molecule]] of [[substrate (biochemistry)|substrate]] at a time. Uniporter channels open in response to a stimulus and allow the free flow of specific molecules.
There are several ways in which the opening of uniporter channels may be regulated:
# [[Voltage]] – Regulated by the difference in voltage across the membrane # [[Stress (physics)|Stress]] – Regulated by physical [[pressure]] on the transporter (as in the [[cochlea]] of the [[ear]]) # [[Ligand]] – Regulated by the binding of a ligand to either the intracellular or extracellular side of the [[cell (biology)|cell]]
Uniporters are involved in many [[Biology|biological]] processes, including [[action potential]]s in [[neuron]]s. Voltage-gated [[sodium channel]]s are involved in the propagation of a [[nerve impulse]] across the neuron. During transmission of the signal from one neuron to the next, [[calcium]] is transported into the [[presynaptic neuron]] by voltage-gated [[calcium channel]]s. [[Potassium leak channel]]s, also regulated by voltage, then help to restore the resting [[membrane potential]] after impulse transmission.
In the ear, [[sound wave]]s cause the stress-regulated channels in the ear to open, sending an impulse to the [[vestibulocochlear nerve]] (VIII).
==See also== * [[Antiporter]] * [[Symporter]]
== References == <references /> * Alberts, Bruce et al. — ''Essential Cell Biology'', 1st edition. Garland Publishing, New York: 1998. * M. G. Wolfersberger: [http://jeb.biologists.org/content/196/1/5.full.pdf ''Uniporters, symporters and antiporters.''] In: ''The Journal of Experimental Biology.'' Band 196, November 1994, S. 5–6, {{ISSN|0022-0949}}. {{PMID|7823043}}. {{Membrane transport}}
[[Category:Integral membrane proteins]] [[Category:Transport phenomena]]

{{Eastern Slavic name|Vasilyevich|Krasko}} {{Infobox person | name = Vyacheslav Vasilyevich Krasko | image = | image_size = | caption = Vyacheslav Krasko | birth_date = {{birth date|1974|08|06}} | birth_place = [[Leningrad]] | death_date = | death_place = | other_names = Vyacheslav Krasko | known_for = traveler, top manager and professional financier | occupation = | nationality = [[Russians|Russian]] }}
'''Vyacheslav Vasilyevich Krasko''' ({{lang-ru|Вячеслáв Васильевич Крaськó}}) (born August 6, 1974 in [[Leningrad]], [[Soviet Union]]) is a [[Russia]]n traveler, top manager and professional financier with a PhD Economics.<ref name="Groscheva">{{Cite web |author = Olga Grosheva |date = 2012-11-08 |url = http://www.kommersant.ru/doc-y/2062728 |script-title = ru:''Туроператор "Новый век" пополнил ряды банкротов'' |publisher = Radio "Kommersant FM" |accessdate = 2013-02-24 |language = ru |archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/6DlwiN69S?url=http://www.kommersant.ru/doc-y/2062728 |archivedate = 2013-01-18 |title = Archived copy |dead-url = no |df = }}</ref> Member of the Union of Russian Around-the-World Travelers.
==Life and education== Krasko graduated [[Saint Petersburg State University of Economics and Finance|St. Petersburg State University of Economics and Finance]], with a specialty in "World Economy". He continued his education in [[France]] at the [[Paris Dauphine University|Economic University of Paris IX-Dauphine]] with the specialty "Management of public and private enterprises".<ref name="Makeeva">{{cite book |author= Makeeva, Sophia V. |date= 2011 |publisher= [[Eksmo]] |location= Moscow |isbn= 978-5-699-48803-2 |pages=354 |language=ru}}</ref>
From 1993 to 1999 he held main posts in the leading Russian banks, and from 1999 to 2010 he was a Financial Director in some large Russian companies.<ref name="Forbes">{{cite web |author = Natalia Kalinina |date = 2012-02-03 |url = http://www.forbes.ru/5bissue5d/issue/2012-02/81640-stranovedenie |title = Страноведениe |publisher = [[Forbes]] |accessdate = 2013-03-11 |language = ru |archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/6DlwoFhMv?url=http://www.forbes.ru/5bissue5d/issue/2012-02/81640-stranovedenie |archivedate = 2013-01-18 |dead-url = no |df = }}</ref><ref name="Osipov">{{cite web |author = Anton Osipov |date = 2010-03-16 |url = http://www.vedomosti.ru/career/news/2010/03/16/969832 |script-title = ru:Финдиректор бросил "дочку" "Базэла" ради кругосветного путешествия |publisher = [[Vedomosti]] |accessdate = 2013-03-11 |language = ru |archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/6DlwyYJWy?url=http://www.vedomosti.ru/career/news/2010/03/16/969832 |archivedate = 2013-01-18 |title = Archived copy |dead-url = no |df = }}</ref><ref name="Mikhalev">{{cite web |author = Nikolay Mikhalev |date = 2008-11-27 |url = http://www.rbcdaily.ru/2008/11/27/market/562949979005442 |script-title = ru:Дерипаска сворачивает стройку |publisher = RBC daily |accessdate = 2013-03-11 |language = ru |archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/6Dlws1eO8?url=http://www.rbcdaily.ru/market/562949979005442 |archivedate = 2013-01-18 |title = Archived copy |dead-url = no |df = }}</ref><ref name="Aminov">{{cite web |author = Khalil Aminov |date = 2007-10-02 |url = http://www.kommersant.ru/Doc-y/810138 |script-title = ru:Параллельные олимпийские игры |publisher = [[Kommersant]] |accessdate = 2012-12-13 |language = ru |archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/6Dlwv4q1T?url=http://www.kommersant.ru/Doc-y/810138 |archivedate = 2013-01-18 |title = Archived copy |dead-url = no |df = }}</ref>
At the beginning of April 2010 he gave up the work of Financial Director and traveled around the world.<ref name="Osipov" /> When he returned in 2011, he was invited in the Union of Russian Around-the-World Travelers and founded his touristic company “The Year of Spring” ({{lang-ru|Год весны}}).
On 10 October 2012 Krasko became the winner of the international photo-competition “People of India” in [[Naggar]] (the Kullu District of [[Himachal Pradesh]], [[India]]).<ref>{{cite web |author = Marina Filippova |date = 2012-10-11 |url = http://kailash.ru/news2/news4819.html |script-title = ru:На севере Индии открылась выставка фотографий российских путешественников "Люди Индии" |publisher = ETC "Kailash" |accessdate = 2013-03-11 |language = ru |archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/6Dlx1v7f4?url=http://kailash.ru/news2/news4819.html |archivedate = 2013-01-18 |title = Archived copy |dead-url = no |df = }}</ref>
Vyacheslav continues to travel: he has been to many places of local conflicts and ecological disasters. In 2013 he’s planning to make a journey entitled, “Ruta del Che” (“The way of Che Guevara”), by motorcycle in South America along the route of [[Ernesto Che Guevara]], and has begun creating a feature-length fictional film, “The Year of Spring” ({{lang-ru|Год весны}}).<ref name="Forbes" />
==The Year of Spring: travel and book== [[File:Map Godvesny.jpg|left|thumb|Round the world trip of Vyacheslav Krasko]] His first travel round the world began April 2010 in [[Asia]] and lasted 407 days.<ref name="Radio">{{cite web |date = 2012-06-19 |url = http://www.radiorus.ru/news.html?id=602802 |script-title = ru:Отказ от чужих целей |publisher = Radio "Russia" |accessdate = 2013-03-11 |language = ru |archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/6Dlx3rZZ3?url=http://www.radiorus.ru/news.html?id=602802 |archivedate = 2013-01-18 |title = Archived copy |dead-url = yes |df = }}</ref>
Beginning he flew from [[Moscow]], he flew to [[Uzbekistan]], then to the East, followed by going South to [[Australia]], then to [[South America]] and [[North America]]; from North America he crossed the [[Atlantic Ocean]] to [[Africa]], then he went across Africa and through the [[Europe]]an countries he came back to Moscow.<ref name="Forbes" /> In total Vyacheslav visited 6 continents, 36 countries and 145 towns and cities, overcoming 137 000 km. The budget of the travel was 33 thousand U.S. dollars.<ref>{{cite web |date = 2010-10-03 |url = http://www.kommersant.ru/doc-y/1781548 |script-title = ru:Вакантное место под солнцем |publisher = Magazine "Ogonek" №39 (5198) |accessdate = 2013-03-11 |language = ru |archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/6Dlx5x2Rx?url=http://www.kommersant.ru/doc-y/1781548 |archivedate = 2013-01-18 |title = Archived copy |dead-url = no |df = }}</ref> The movements of the traveler were watched by a large number of people on-line at his website.<ref name="Radio" />
At the end of the journey Vyacheslav decided to come back to his homeland in order to share his new knowledge with others.<ref>{{cite web |author = Nadezhda Kulikova |date = 2011-04-18 |url = http://www.mr7.ru/articles/41376/ |script-title = ru:Вокруг света: в погоне за детской мечтой |publisher = The newspaper "Moj rayon" |accessdate = 2013-03-11 |language = ru |archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/6DlxADqT0?url=http://www.mr7.ru/articles/41376/ |archivedate = 2013-01-18 |title = Archived copy |dead-url = no |df = }}</ref> His desire to share paired with the wishes of many people prompted him to publish a book about the project, in which everyone could feel the emotions and impressions of the traveler.
It was completed in [[Sarankot]] – a small village near [[Pokhara]] ([[Nepal]]), which is situated 5000 ft above sea level.<ref name="FOTO&VIDEO">{{cite web |date = 2012-06-14 |url = http://www.foto-video.ru/art/albums/60928/ |script-title = ru:ИД "Постум" выпустил книгу путешественника Вячеслава Красько "Год Весны" |publisher = Magazine "FOTO&VIDEO" |accessdate = 2013-03-02 |language = ru |archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/6DlxFlxtj?url=http://www.foto-video.ru/art/albums/60928/ |archivedate = 2013-01-18 |title = Archived copy |dead-url = no |df = }}</ref> This book ([[The Year of Spring (book)|The Year of Spring: ''The Travel What Lasts a Year'']]) is not a novel, autobiography, or itinerary.<ref>{{cite web | author = Georgy Osipov | date = 2012-12-10 | url = http://www.foto-video.ru/art/albums/60928/ | script-title=ru:Сделал сам | publisher = Magazine "Turbiznes" | accessdate = 2013-03-02 | language = ru }}</ref> It is a collection of stories of wanderings that touches on remembrance, love, exotic landscapes, amazing feelings, thoughts, excerpts of lovely books, the life’s hard mountain climb and descent into the depths of one’s own soul.<ref name="FOTO&VIDEO" /><ref>{{cite web |date = 2012-06-20 |url = http://prochtenie.ru/passage/25812 |script-title = ru:Вячеслав Красько. Год Весны |publisher = LLC "Reader" |accessdate = 2013-03-11 |language = ru |archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/6DlxILhdd?url=http://prochtenie.ru/passage/25812 |archivedate = 2013-01-18 |title = Archived copy |dead-url = no |df = }}</ref> Critics describe the main driving force of the book and basis of all Vyacheslav Krasko’s travels to be freedom and happiness.
==See also== * [[Travel]] * [[List of circumnavigations]] * [[Adventure travel]] * [[The Year of Spring (book)|The Year of Spring: ''The Travel What Lasts a Year'']]

{{Infobox organization | name = Young Bosnia | native_name = Mlada Bosna | image = Young Bosnia members.jpg | image_size = 200px | alt = | caption = Some of the members | map = | map_size = | map_alt = | map_caption = | abbreviation = | motto = | predecessor = | merged = | successor = | formation = 1911 | founder = Unknown | extinction = after 28 June 1914 | merger = | type = [[revolutionary organization]] | status = | purpose = [[creation of Yugoslavia]] through unification of Bosnia and Herzegovina with Serbia | headquarters = | location = | coords = | region = | services = | membership = | language = | sec_gen = | leader_title = | leader_name = | leader_title2 = | leader_name2 = | leader_title3 = | leader_name3 = | leader_title4 = | leader_name4 = | board_of_directors = | key_people = [[Gavrilo Princip]] | main_organ = | parent_organization = | subsidiaries = | secessions = | affiliations = [[Narodna Odbrana]] and [[Black Hand (Serbia)|Black Hand]] | budget = | staff = | volunteers = | slogan = | remarks = | formerly = | footnotes = }} '''Young Bosnia''' ({{lang-sh|Mlada Bosna}}/Млада Босна) was a [[revolutionary movement]] active in the [[Condominium of Bosnia and Herzegovina]] before [[World War I]]. The members were predominantly school students, primarily [[Bosnian Serbs]], but also [[Bosnian Muslims]] and [[Bosnian Croats]]. There were two key ideologies promoted amongst the members of the group, the [[Yugoslavist]] (unification into a [[Yugoslavia]]), and the [[Pan-Serb]] (unification into [[Serbia]]). Young Bosnia was inspired from a variety of ideas, movements, and events; such as German [[romanticism]], [[anarchism]], Russian [[revolutionary socialism]], [[Fyodor Dostoyevsky]], [[Friedrich Nietzsche]], and the [[Battle of Kosovo]]. ==Background== The rise to power of the popular [[Karađorđević dynasty]] in Serbia in the 1900s after the [[May Overthrow]] of the Obrenović dynasty by the Serbian Army in 1903, stimulated support by both Serbs and South Slavs for their unification into a state led by Belgrade.{{sfn|Djokić|2003|p=59}} Support for revolutionary Yugoslavism in Bosnia grew with the rise of the [[Serbo-Croatian Progressive Organization]] in 1911, and drew in support for the cause from Serbs as well as Croats and some Muslims. ==Formation, membership and ideology== It was formed during the 1900s in the [[Condominium of Bosnia and Herzegovina]] (an annexed condominium of [[Austria-Hungary]]), with significant influence from neighbouring [[Kingdom of Serbia|Serbia]].{{cite book|author=John R. Lampe|title=Yugoslavia as History: Twice There Was a Country|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=AZ1x7gvwx_8C&pg=PA90|date=28 March 2000|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=978-0-521-77401-7|pages=90–}} The ideologue of Young Bosnia{{cite book|author=Belgrade (Serbia). Vojni muzej Jugoslovenske narodne armije|title=Fourteen centuries of struggle for freedom|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=2m8MAQAAMAAJ|year=1968|publisher=The Military Museum|page=II }} and [[tyrannicide]] as its method of the political struggle, was [[Vladimir Gaćinović]].{{cite book|last1=Лесковац|first1=Младен|last2=Форишковић|first2=Александар|last3=Попов|first3=Чедомир|title=Српски биографски речник|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ozYYAQAAIAAJ|year=2004|publisher=Будућност|page=634}} In one letter to Dedijer, one of revolutionaries from Herzegovina (Božidar Zečević) stated that the name of Young Bosnia was first mentioned by [[Petar Kočić]] in journal "Homeland" ({{lang-sr|Отаџбина}}) in 1907. In 1911 Gaćinović published an article titled "Young Bosnia" in Almanac ({{lang-sr|Алманах}}) published by Prosvjeta.{{sfn|Dedijer|1966|p=831}} The Serbian National Organization of Petar Kočić had ties with the Young Bosnia.{{sfn|Banac|1988}} Young Bosnia received some assistance by the [[Black Hand (Serbia)|Black Hand]] – a secret organization founded by several members of the [[Serbian Army]]. On the other hand, [[Vladimir Gaćinović]] was the only Young Bosnia leader to join [[Black Hand (Serbia)|Black Hand]],{{cite book|last=Glenny|first=Misha|title=The Balkans: Nationalism, War, and the Great Powers, 1804-2012: New and Updated|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=LJqYbknmxjYC&pg=PT244|date=5 September 2012|publisher=House of Anansi|isbn=978-1-77089-274-3|page=}} although he condemned the assassination in a letter (presumably as a way to strip responsibility).{{sfn|Dedijer|1966|p=522}} The members were predominantly school students,{{cite book|last=Stevenson|first=David|title=1914 - 1918:The History of the First World War|year=2004|publisher=Penguin Books|isbn=978-0-14-026817-1|pages=11}} primarily [[Serbs]] but also [[Bosniaks]] and [[Croats]].{{sfn|Djokić|2003|p=24}} There were several motivations promoted amongst different members of the group. There were members who promoted [[Yugoslavism|Yugoslavist]] aims of pan-South Slav unification of territories including Bosnia into a [[Yugoslavia]].{{cite book|author=Neven Andjelic|title=Bosnia-Herzegovina: The End of a Legacy|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=YO64tcuC2aQC|year=2003|publisher=Psychology Press|isbn=978-0-7146-5485-0}}{{cite book|author= Matjaž Klemenčič, Mitja Žagar |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ORSMBFwjAKcC&pg=PA56|title=The Former Yugoslavia's Diverse Peoples: A Reference Sourcebook|publisher=ABC Clio|year=|page=56}}{{sfn|Banac|1988}} There were members who promoted [[Serbian nationalism|Serbian nationalist]] aims of pan-Serb unification into [[Serbia]].{{sfn|Banac|1988}} Young Bosnia was inspired from a variety of ideas, movements, and events; such as German [[romanticism]], [[anarchism]],{{cite web|author=Trivo Indic|url=http://www.katesharpleylibrary.net/1c5bbd|title=The anarchist tradition on Yugoslav soil|publisher=Umanità Nova|date=27 May 1990|accessdate=17 October 2014}} Russian [[revolutionary socialism]], [[Fyodor Dostoyevsky]], [[Friedrich Nietzsche]], and the [[Battle of Kosovo]].{{cite book|author=Stevan K. Pavlowitch|title=Serbia: The History of an Idea|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=u46G_l3Cz20C|year=2002|publisher=New York University Press|isbn=978-0-8147-6708-5|pages=90–91}} == Assassination of Archduke Franz Ferdinand of Austria == {{Main article|Assassination of Archduke Franz Ferdinand of Austria}} Two notable organizations are referred to in connection with Young Bosnia: [[Narodna Odbrana]] and [[Black Hand (Serbia)|Black Hand]]. During a Serbian [[kangaroo court]] in French-occupied [[Salonika]] in 1916–17, Chief of Serbian Military Intelligence [[Dragutin Dimitrijević Apis]] testified that he had organized the [[assassination of Archduke Franz Ferdinand of Austria]], in Sarajevo on 28 June 1914, (the assassin was [[Gavrilo Princip]]). In the process, he used not only his power over elements of the Serbian military, but also the Black Hand. Leaders of the Black Hand in turn had penetrated Narodna Odbrana and used that organization to infiltrate the arms and assassins into Sarajevo.
''"The political union of the Yugoslavs [..] was my basic idea [..] I am a Yugoslav nationalist, aiming for the unification of all Yugoslavs, and I do not care what form of state, but it must be free from Austria"''
-[[Gavrilo Princip]] during his trial{{sfn|Banac|1988}}
[[File:Vidovdanski heroji.jpg|thumbnail|Vidovdan Heroes' Memorial in Sarajevo]] Claimed members of Young Bosnia who participated in the assassination were: *[[Danilo Ilić]] (1891 – 3 February 1915) *[[Veljko Čubrilović]] (1 July 1886 – 3 February 1915) *Miško Jovanović (executed 3 February 1915) *[[Nedeljko Čabrinović]] (2 February 1895 – 20 January 1916) *[[Vladimir Gaćinović]] (25 May 1890 – 11 August 1917) *[[Trifko Grabež]] (June 1895 – February 1916) *[[Gavrilo Princip]] (25 July 1894 – 28 April 1918) *[[Muhamed Mehmedbašić]] (1886 – 29 May 1943) *[[Cvjetko Popović]] (1896 – 9 June 1980) *[[Vaso Čubrilović]] (14 January 1897 – 11 June 1990) An evening before the assassination of Archduke Franz Ferdinand, Princip, Čabrinović and Ilić visited the grave of [[Bogdan Žerajić]] for the last time.{{cite book|title=Stand To!: The Journal of the Western Front Association|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=gPAWAQAAIAAJ|year=2003|publisher=The Association|page=44|quote=On the evening before 28 June 1914 Princip, Cabrinovic and Ilic paid a last visit to the grave of Bogdan Zerajic in Sarajevo. Zerajic had planned an assault ...}} Žerajić's proclamation "He who wants to live, let him die. He who wants to die, let him live", was quoted by [[Gavrilo Princip]] in one of the songs he wrote ({{lang-sr|Ал право је рекао пре Жерајић, соко сиви: Ко хоће да живи, нек мре, Ко хоће да мре, нек живи}}).{{cite book|last=Marković|first=Marko|title=Članci i ogledi|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=1UYjAAAAMAAJ|year=1961|page=193}} ==Legacy== ===Museum of Young Bosnia=== The Museum of Young Bosnia was built in the period of [[Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia|SFR Yugoslavia]] in 1953, at the place where the assassination took place. It commemorates the assassins, popularly known in the Kingdom of Yugoslavia as the "[[Vidovdan]] heroes". At the front of the museum was a plaque, inscribed: "From this place, on 28 June 1914, Gavrilo Princip, expressed with his shot the people's revolt against tyranny and their centuries-old struggle for freedom. (Са овога мјеста 28. јуна 1914. године Гаврило Принцип својим пуцњем изрази народни протест против тираније и вјековну тежњу наших народа за слободом.)" In 1992, soldiers of the [[Army of the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina]] destroyed both the plaque and Princip's footprints. German forces had removed the 1930 plaque in 1941. The [[Museum of Sarajevo 1878–1918|museum]] still exists today, but nowadays documents aspects of life in Bosnia & Herzegovina during Austro-Hungarian rule. ==See also== * [[Višnja Mosić]] ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==Sources== {{refbegin}} * {{cite book|last=Banac|first=Ivo|title=The National Question in Yugoslavia: Origins, History, Politics|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=KfqbujXqQBkC|year=1988|publisher=Cornell University Press|isbn=0-8014-9493-1|ref=harv}} * {{cite journal|last=Blakley|first=Patrick R.
